name: biomni-predict-o-glycosylation-hotspots
title: Biomni: Predict O Glycosylation Hotspots
content:
Overview

This tool predicts O-linked glycosylation hotspots in protein sequences using heuristic scoring based on local amino acid composition and structural context. Unlike N-glycosylation which has a well-defined sequon, O-glycosylation occurs on serine and threonine residues without a strict consensus motif. This tool identifies regions enriched in S/T residues and applies contextual rules (such as proline proximity) to score potential O-glycosylation hotspots. O-glycosylation plays critical roles in mucin-type proteins, extracellular domains, and protein-protein interactions, making hotspot prediction valuable for protein engineering and therapeutic design.

Input Parameters

  • sequence (string, required): The protein sequence to analyze in single-letter amino acid code (e.g., 'MTSPPSTSTPAPSTPVPTTPSS'). The sequence should contain standard amino acid letters.
  • window (integer, optional, default: 7): The sliding window size used to calculate local S/T enrichment. A larger window considers broader regional context, while a smaller window focuses on immediate local composition. Typical values range from 5 to 11.
  • min_st_fraction (float, optional, default: 0.4): The minimum fraction of serine and threonine residues within the window to consider it a potential hotspot. Values range from 0.0 to 1.0. Higher values (e.g., 0.5) identify only highly S/T-enriched regions, while lower values (e.g., 0.3) are more permissive.
  • disallow_proline_next (boolean, optional, default: true): Whether to exclude S/T residues immediately followed by proline from hotspot consideration. Proline in the +1 position often inhibits O-glycosylation, so this filter improves prediction accuracy.

Input Format

The input should be a JSON file with the following structure:

{
  "sequence": "MTSPPSTSTPAPSTPVPTTPSS",
  "window": 7,
  "min_st_fraction": 0.4,
  "disallow_proline_next": true
}

Biological Use Case

O-glycosylation hotspot prediction is important for:

  • Mucin-type protein engineering: Mucins are heavily O-glycosylated proteins that form protective barriers on epithelial surfaces. Identifying hotspots helps design mucin-mimetic therapeutics with desired properties.
  • Therapeutic protein optimization: O-glycosylation affects protein half-life, immunogenicity, and protease resistance. Engineering hotspots can modulate these properties in biologics.
  • Fc region engineering: Some therapeutic antibodies have O-glycosylation in hinge regions. Predicting and modulating these sites can alter effector functions and stability.
  • Vaccine design: Many viral and bacterial glycoproteins contain O-glycosylation hotspots that influence immune recognition. Understanding these regions aids in immunogen design.
  • Bioprocessing optimization: O-glycosylation patterns vary between expression systems. Predicting hotspots helps anticipate glycoform heterogeneity in recombinant production.

Output

The tool generates a JSON file (o_glycosylation_hotspots.json) containing scored regions and individual residues with high O-glycosylation potential. The output includes position information, local S/T density scores, and contextual features that contribute to the hotspot prediction. This information guides site-directed mutagenesis strategies and helps prioritize experimental validation of predicted O-glycosylation sites.

Category

glycoengineering
